item description: Determine the unit rate using fractions and whole numbers to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas, and other quantities measured in like or different units. For example, if a person walks ½ mile in each ¼ hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction ½ ∕¼ miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour.

item description: Determine the product of an expression using order of operations.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide integers and other rational numbers.

item description: Use a given two-way table containing data from two populations to determine the probability of an event.
Standard Description:
Use data from a random sample to draw inferences about a population with an unknown characteristic
of interest. Generate multiple samples (or simulated samples) of the same size to gauge the variation in
estimates or predictions. For example, estimate the mean word length in a book by randomly sampling words from the book; predict the winner of a school election based on randomly sampled survey data. Gauge how far off the estimate or prediction might be.

item description: Determine whether the graphed relationship is proportional; use rate and ratio language to analyze the relationship; and write an equation to describe a proportional relationship.
Standard Description: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

item description: Determine the quotient when dividing a decimal number by a decimal number that has a value less than one.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide integers and other rational numbers.

item description: Use the four operations to determine the value of a given multi-step expression containing fractions.
Standard Description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with integers and other rational numbers.2

item description: Compute with rational numbers representing temperature changes in a real-world context.
Standard Description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with integers and other rational numbers.2

item description: Determine which two-dimensional figure results from slicing a three-dimensional figure in a given way.
Standard Description: Describe the shape of the two-dimensional face of the figure that results from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.

item description: Solve a multi-step real-life problem posed with a positive whole number, percent, and a fraction.
Standard Description: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example, if a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1 ∕10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9¾ inches long in the center of a door that is 27½ inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; This estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

item description: Determine the sum of two numbers expressed as absolute values.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract integers and other rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.

item description: Determine which sampling strategy will result in a representative sample of a population.
Standard Description:
Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of
the population; Generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is
representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative
samples and support valid inferences.

item description: Given a real-world context, create an equation and an inequality with variables, and use them to solve problems.
Standard Description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

item description: Determine if a unique triangle can be formed using a given set of conditions.
Standard Description: Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology) two-dimensional geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.

item description: Create correct comparison statements about mean and mean absolute deviation based on line plots.
Standard Description:
Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
For example, the mean height of players on the basketball team is 10 cm greater than the mean height of players on the soccer team and both distributions have similar variability (mean absolute deviation) of about 5cm. The difference between the mean heights of the two teams (10 cm) is about twice the variability (5 cm) on either team. On a dot plot, the separation between the two distributions of heights is noticeable.

item description: Determine the probability of a given compound event by using a tree diagram.
Standard Description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

item description: Determine an equivalent expression to a given expression representing a real-world context.
Standard Description: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related. For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that “increase by 5%” is the same as “multiply by 1.05.” A shirt at a clothing store is on sale for 20% off the regular price, “p”. The discount can be expressed as 0.2p. The new price for the shirt can be expressed as p – 0.2p or 0.8p.

item description: Determine the circumference and the area of a given circle.
Standard Description: Circles and measurement

item description: Use the distributive property to simplify a linear expression.
Standard Description: Apply properties of operations to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients. For example, 4x + 2 = 2(2x +1) and -3(x –5∕3) = -3x + 5.

item description: Using a uniform probability model, determine the probabilities of events expressed as decimals, fractions, or percents.
Standard Description: Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.

item description: Solve a multi-step percent problem using proportional relationships involving markdowns.
Standard Description: Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step ratio, rate, and percent problems. For example: simple interest, tax, price increases and discounts, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

item description: Determine which addition expression is equivalent to a given subtraction expression.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract integers and other rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.

item description: Determine which expression is equivalent to a given expression.
Standard Description: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related. For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that “increase by 5%” is the same as “multiply by 1.05.” A shirt at a clothing store is on sale for 20% off the regular price, “p”. The discount can be expressed as 0.2p. The new price for the shirt can be expressed as p – 0.2p or 0.8p.

item description: Graph the solution set of an inequality that represents a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

item description: Compute a unit rate associated with ratios of fractions in a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas, and other quantities measured in like or different units. For example, if a person walks ½ mile in each ¼ hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction ½ ∕¼ miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour.

item description: Solve a real-world problem that involves fractions and mixed numbers using operations.
Standard Description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with integers and other rational numbers.2

item description: Determine the likelihood of an event and calculate the probability of other events in a real-world context.
Standard Description: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around ½ indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

item description: Determine the product of a negative fraction multiplied by a negative fraction, and then express the product as a rational decimal number.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide integers and other rational numbers.

item description: Express the difference between two means in terms of the mean absolute deviation.
Standard Description:
Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
For example, the mean height of players on the basketball team is 10 cm greater than the mean height of players on the soccer team and both distributions have similar variability (mean absolute deviation) of about 5cm. The difference between the mean heights of the two teams (10 cm) is about twice the variability (5 cm) on either team. On a dot plot, the separation between the two distributions of heights is noticeable.

item description: Expand a linear expression with a rational coefficient.
Standard Description: Apply properties of operations to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients. For example, 4x + 2 = 2(2x +1) and -3(x –5∕3) = -3x + 5.

item description: Solve a two-step equation.
Standard Description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

item description: Convert a value from one system of measurement to another using operations.
Standard Description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with integers and other rational numbers.2

item description: Write an equation to model a given written scenario based on a real-world context.
Standard Description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

item description: Determine which proportion represents a given real-world relationship.
Standard Description: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

item description: Determine the solution of a percent increase problem with real-world context.
Standard Description: Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step ratio, rate, and percent problems. For example: simple interest, tax, price increases and discounts, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

item description: Solve a real-world, multi-step problem involving mixed numbers, percents, and whole numbers.
Standard Description: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example, if a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1 ∕10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9¾ inches long in the center of a door that is 27½ inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; This estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

item description: Determine the unit rate in a multi-step problem, given a real-world scenario.
Standard Description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas, and other quantities measured in like or different units. For example, if a person walks ½ mile in each ¼ hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction ½ ∕¼ miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour.

item description: Use facts about angles to write and solve equations that can be used to find the measures of unknown angles in a diagram.
Standard Description: Use facts about supplementary, complementary, vertical, and adjacent angles in a multi-step problem to write simple equations and use them to solve for an unknown angle in a figure.

item description: Determine the unit rate in a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

item description: Determine the number of data that lie between the means of two data sets.
Standard Description:
Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
For example, the mean height of players on the basketball team is 10 cm greater than the mean height of players on the soccer team and both distributions have similar variability (mean absolute deviation) of about 5cm. The difference between the mean heights of the two teams (10 cm) is about twice the variability (5 cm) on either team. On a dot plot, the separation between the two distributions of heights is noticeable.

item description: Choose an expression that can be used to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

item description: Use operations with a fraction and a percentage to solve a real-world problem and represent the solution in a fraction model.
Standard Description: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example, if a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1 ∕10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9¾ inches long in the center of a door that is 27½ inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; This estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

item description: Use operations with positive and negative rational numbers to solve mathematical problems.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide integers and other rational numbers.

item description: Apply the distributive property to determine which expression is equivalent to a given expression.
Standard Description: Apply properties of operations to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients. For example, 4x + 2 = 2(2x +1) and -3(x –5∕3) = -3x + 5.

item description: Identify multiple rates associated with given fractional ratios in a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas, and other quantities measured in like or different units. For example, if a person walks ½ mile in each ¼ hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction ½ ∕¼ miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour.

item description: Apply properties of addition to determine which expression is not equivalent to a given expression.
Standard Description: Apply properties of operations to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients. For example, 4x + 2 = 2(2x +1) and -3(x –5∕3) = -3x + 5.

item description: Determine which equation models a proportional relationship shown in a table.
Standard Description: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

item description: Determine the scale used in a given real-world context.
Standard Description: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, such as computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.

item description: Represent distance on a number line using an absolute value expression.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract integers and other rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.

item description: Solve an equation of the form px + q = r.
Standard Description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

item description: Determine the likelihood of an event in a real-world context.
Standard Description: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around ½ indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

item description: Solve a multi-step, real-world problem by converting units.
Standard Description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with integers and other rational numbers.2

item description: Determine which sampling strategy will produce a valid sample that represents a specific population.
Standard Description:
Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of
the population; Generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is
representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative
samples and support valid inferences.

item description: Determine which range of expected probabilities best predicts a random outcome.
Standard Description: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability. For example, when rolling a number cube 600 times, predict that a 3 or 6 would be rolled roughly 200 times, but probably not exactly 200 times.

item description: Complete statements to compare the medians and ranges of two data sets.
Standard Description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations. For example, decide whether the words in a chapter of a seventh-grade science book are generally longer than the words in a chapter of a fourth-grade science book.

item description: Solve real-world problems involving area and volume for right prisms of varying dimensions.
Standard Description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume, and surface area of two- and
three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.

item description: Determine the probability of a compound event, given a tree diagram.
Standard Description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

item description: Use proportional reasoning to solve a real-world problem and write an equation to represent the proportional relationship shown in a table.
Standard Description: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

item description: Determine which expression can be used to represent a real-world problem involving area.
Standard Description: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related. For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that “increase by 5%” is the same as “multiply by 1.05.” A shirt at a clothing store is on sale for 20% off the regular price, “p”. The discount can be expressed as 0.2p. The new price for the shirt can be expressed as p – 0.2p or 0.8p.

item description: Use data from a random sample to draw an inference about a population and create a bar graph to represent the inference.

Standard Description: Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step ratio, rate, and percent problems. For example: simple interest, tax, price increases and discounts, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

item description: Solve a real-world problem involving addition and subtraction with decimals.
Standard Description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with integers and other rational numbers.2

item description: Solve a real-world problem involving the area of a two-dimensional object.
Standard Description:
Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving area, volume, and surface area of two- and
three-dimensional objects composed of triangles, quadrilaterals, polygons, cubes, and right prisms.

item description: Use ratio and proportional reasoning to calculate actual distance given a scale on a map.

item description: Solve a multi-step real-world ratio problem.
Standard Description: Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step ratio, rate, and percent problems. For example: simple interest, tax, price increases and discounts, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

item description: Recognize if data represented on a graph is proportional, solve a problem involving proportions on a graph, and write an equation that can be used to represent the relationship between quantities.
Standard Description: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

item description: Determine which expression is equivalent to a given expression.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide integers and other rational numbers.

item description: Determine which expression is equivalent to a given expression.
Standard Description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with integers and other rational numbers.2

item description: Apply properties to add linear expressions in a real-world context.
Standard Description: Apply properties of operations to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients. For example, 4x + 2 = 2(2x +1) and -3(x –5∕3) = -3x + 5.

item description: Determine which expressions can be used to represent a real-world problem involving price markups and markdowns.
Standard Description: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related. For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that “increase by 5%” is the same as “multiply by 1.05.” A shirt at a clothing store is on sale for 20% off the regular price, “p”. The discount can be expressed as 0.2p. The new price for the shirt can be expressed as p – 0.2p or 0.8p.

item description: Determine which expression is equivalent to a given expression.
Standard Description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with integers and other rational numbers.2

item description: Determine which tree diagram correctly models the probabilities of compound events.
Standard Description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

item description: Determine the value of a variable that will make an algebraic expression positive and rational.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide integers and other rational numbers.

item description: Plot the value of a rational expression on a number line.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of addition and subtraction to add and subtract integers and other rational numbers; represent addition and subtraction on a horizontal or vertical number line diagram.

item description: Solve multi-step real-life problems using fractions, decimals, and whole numbers.
Standard Description: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example, if a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1 ∕10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9¾ inches long in the center of a door that is 27½ inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; This estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

item description: Determine the number of triangles that could be drawn using a given set of side lengths.
Standard Description: Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology) two-dimensional geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.

item description: Determine the probability of an event using a uniform probability model.
Standard Description: Develop a probability model and use it to find probabilities of events. Compare probabilities from a model to observed frequencies; if the agreement is not good, explain possible sources of the discrepancy.

item description: Determine which two-dimensional figure will be the result from slicing a given three-dimensional figure.
Standard Description: Describe the shape of the two-dimensional face of the figure that results from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.

item description: Determine dimensions of a scaled rectangle given the original rectangle and scale.
Standard Description: Solve problems involving scale drawings of geometric figures, such as computing actual lengths and areas from a scale drawing and reproducing a scale drawing at a different scale.

item description: Identify which set is most likely to produce an event that will match a given probability.
Standard Description: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around ½ indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

item description: Solve a multi-step real-world percent problem.
Standard Description: Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step ratio, rate, and percent problems. For example: simple interest, tax, price increases and discounts, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.

item description: Determine the probability of a compound event using a tree diagram and a fair coin.
Standard Description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

item description: Solve a problem that involves making comparisons between two population medians using data from two random samples.
Standard Description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations. For example, decide whether the words in a chapter of a seventh-grade science book are generally longer than the words in a chapter of a fourth-grade science book.

item description: Determine which sampling strategy will produce a valid representative sample for a given population.
Standard Description:
Understand that statistics can be used to gain information about a population by examining a sample of
the population; Generalizations about a population from a sample are valid only if the sample is
representative of that population. Understand that random sampling tends to produce representative
samples and support valid inferences.

item description: Determine which proportion can be used to find a missing value, given a scale.
Standard Description: Recognize and represent proportional relationships between quantities.

item description: Determine which expression represents a factored form of a given expression.
Standard Description: Apply properties of operations to add, subtract, factor, and expand linear expressions with rational coefficients. For example, 4x + 2 = 2(2x +1) and -3(x –5∕3) = -3x + 5.

item description: Approximate the probability of a chance event by analyzing its long-run relative frequency, given the relative frequency of a spinner.
Standard Description: Approximate the probability of a chance event by collecting data on the chance process that produces it and observing its long-run relative frequency, and predict the approximate relative frequency given the probability. For example, when rolling a number cube 600 times, predict that a 3 or 6 would be rolled roughly 200 times, but probably not exactly 200 times.

item description: Determine unit rates associated with ratios of fractions and use them to solve real-world problems.
Standard Description: Compute unit rates associated with ratios of fractions, including ratios of lengths, areas, and other quantities measured in like or different units. For example, if a person walks ½ mile in each ¼ hour, compute the unit rate as the complex fraction ½ ∕¼ miles per hour, equivalently 2 miles per hour.

item description: Determine which solution satisfies given simple equations.
Standard Description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

item description: Determine which statement correctly describes a way that a three-dimensional figure could be sliced to result in a given two-dimensional shape.
Standard Description: Describe the shape of the two-dimensional face of the figure that results from slicing three-dimensional figures, as in plane sections of right rectangular prisms and right rectangular pyramids.

item description: Determine a decimal equivalent of a given fraction.
Standard Description: Apply and extend previous understandings of multiplication and division and of fractions to multiply and divide integers and other rational numbers.

item description: Determine the possible mean and mean absolute deviation for two sets of data in a real-world context.
Standard Description: Use measures of center and measures of variability for numerical data from random samples to draw informal comparative inferences about two populations. For example, decide whether the words in a chapter of a seventh-grade science book are generally longer than the words in a chapter of a fourth-grade science book.

item description: Extend a pattern to find a number in the pattern, and choose an expression that represents the general rule of the pattern.
Standard Description: Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

item description: Determine which expressions are equivalent to a verbal description of a real-world context.
Standard Description: Understand that rewriting an expression in different forms in a problem context can shed light on the problem and how the quantities in it are related. For example, a + 0.05a = 1.05a means that “increase by 5%” is the same as “multiply by 1.05.” A shirt at a clothing store is on sale for 20% off the regular price, “p”. The discount can be expressed as 0.2p. The new price for the shirt can be expressed as p – 0.2p or 0.8p.
Use variables to represent quantities in a real-world or mathematical problem, and construct simple equations and inequalities to solve problems by reasoning about the quantities.

item description: Solve a multi-step, real-world problem involving percent increases with money.
Standard Description: Solve multi-step real-life and mathematical problems posed with positive and negative rational numbers in any form (whole numbers, fractions, and decimals), using tools strategically. Apply properties of operations to calculate with numbers in any form; convert between forms as appropriate; and assess the reasonableness of answers using mental computation and estimation strategies. For example, if a woman making $25 an hour gets a 10% raise, she will make an additional 1 ∕10 of her salary an hour, or $2.50, for a new salary of $27.50. If you want to place a towel bar 9¾ inches long in the center of a door that is 27½ inches wide, you will need to place the bar about 9 inches from each edge; This estimate can be used as a check on the exact computation.

item description: Use operations on integers and rational numbers to solve a real-world problem.
Standard Description: Solve real-world and mathematical problems involving the four operations with integers and other rational numbers.2

item description: Identify the outcomes in a sample space represented by a tree diagram.
Standard Description: Find probabilities of compound events using organized lists, tables, tree diagrams, and simulation.

item description: Determine whether the given conditions of a triangle represent a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.
Standard Description: Draw (freehand, with ruler and protractor, and with technology) two-dimensional geometric shapes with given conditions. Focus on constructing triangles from three measures of angles or sides, noticing when the conditions determine a unique triangle, more than one triangle, or no triangle.

item description: Determine the likelihood of events occurring based on the probability of a list of chance events.
Standard Description: Understand that the probability of a chance event is a number between 0 and 1 that expresses the likelihood of the event occurring. Larger numbers indicate greater likelihood. A probability near 0 indicates an unlikely event, a probability around ½ indicates an event that is neither unlikely nor likely, and a probability near 1 indicates a likely event.

item description: Determine the radius and the area given the diameter of a circle.
Standard Description: Circles and measurement

item description: Determine the difference of the ranges of data displayed in a double box plot.
Standard Description:
Informally assess the degree of visual overlap of two numerical data distributions with similar variabilities, measuring the difference between the centers by expressing it as a multiple of a measure of variability.
For example, the mean height of players on the basketball team is 10 cm greater than the mean height of players on the soccer team and both distributions have similar variability (mean absolute deviation) of about 5cm. The difference between the mean heights of the two teams (10 cm) is about twice the variability (5 cm) on either team. On a dot plot, the separation between the two distributions of heights is noticeable.

item description: Use proportional relationships to solve a multi-step ratio problem.
Standard Description: Use proportional relationships to solve multi-step ratio, rate, and percent problems. For example: simple interest, tax, price increases and discounts, gratuities and commissions, fees, percent increase and decrease, percent error.
